It was the Royal couple's first visit to Northern Ireland's best known tourist attraction. The causeway formed when molten rock was forced up through fissures in the earth to form a lava plateau. The Unesco World Heritage Site is made up of three columns of rock which rose up out of the Atlantic Ocean and eventually collapsed when the Irish Sea rose in strength . A lot about the site , including the columns , is known as Irish mythology . However , the most enduring feature is the pinnacles , or mountain tops which appear to stand on top of the columns . On 30 January 1915, England played Scotland in a charity match organised by former England international and Northampton Saints captain Edgar Mobbs. The aim of the match was to raise some funds for the injured and sick soldiers in the Battle of Jutland, which had left thousands of men killed or wounded. Mobbs, who was himself a member of the 1914-18 Indian Army, had been chosen to represent the English, and he played the first four Tests of the war for the British side, as well as several ODIs between November 1915 and February 1916.

Officers have found no evidence for a forced entry into his backpack, nor do they believe he made any deliberate decision to take his own life. It is thought that he became disorientated during the climb, but fell into the water. He drowned, around seven metres below the water, when he was swept away by an avalanche as he tried to take a photo.

Ten countries which account for just 2.5% of the global GDP are sheltering more than half the world's 21 million refugees, says a report published jointly by Oxfam and the Australian government. By 2020, the number of refugees will have risen to 56 million - that's 16 of the world's 30 top-grossing economies.

It's important to understand that, just because a country is rich, for Oxfam and the government of Australia to see it as a poor country with little influence is wrong. To the contrary, Australia is a major player in the global economic growth and development system. This report, written by Oxfam's Australian and Japanese general secretaries, explains who the refugees actually are.

The top 10 countries (and territories) hosting refugees

A series of mathematical formulas can help explain the creation of the universe, from the Big Bang to the laws of physics.

The maths behind them was discovered after an international team of scientists used a computer to test what happened to the energy of the universe at various points in time.

The research, published in the journal Scientific Reports, looked at three dimensions of the space-time fabric.

For each axis, there is a 'big bang' for which we can calculate the temperature and density conditions as they changed.

A second dimension is the expansion of space-time over time.

The Prison Service has said 256 places at HMP Featherstone, near Wolverhampton will be changed. The category C spaces will make way for category B cells and new Category C prisons.

The new category C cells are all 10 metres by 7 metres. They have a height limit of 2.35 metres and a width of 1.35. The prisoners will have a single door through which there will be one opening to the outside.

The change is due to come into force in the second quarter of 2013. They will house up to 2,500 prisoners. The new category C prisons will be on a temporary basis while the standard Category B jails at Wolverhampton and Charing Cross are put into operation.


The UK prison estate currently houses more than 200,000 prisoners.


The changes will save about £100m a year and would also see HMP Featherstone's capacity reduced by 75 prisoners – from 2,900 to 2,700.

Before he died, he published an autobiographical account based on his experiences of the First World War and his subsequent career as an officer in the Army of the Thames. He died suddenly in 1913, aged only 50, and was buried in the Blues' family plot at the old London Athletic Grounds stadium.

His father, Henry, and grandfather, Thomas, who had served in the Navy, were each buried at the same plot after their deaths. The original memorial consisted of three brass plaques, each inscribed with the names of the boys. By the 1950s, however, more plaques were added. completed: Jack Whitley was The Blues ' goalkeeper during their first season in the top flight , playing for Chelsea between 1907 and 1914 . Before he died , he asked to be buried with a Chelsea top which he wore when he was under pressure in cup games . His coffin was adorned with a Chelsea flag and club badge , which he was wearing at the time of his death . Chelsea 's crest has never been replicated exactly . The club first used a small shield as their crest in 1902 , followed by a bigger version in 1905 . They later used the second set of variations between 1938 - 1960 . However , the modern crest , which features the badge surrounded by two leaves , was created from scratch in 1967 , originally named the club 's 'crest of Championship ' . The original shield was later re- adopted by Chelsea 's club crest .  * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *

"From the beginning, it has been seen as an icon because it's emblematic of American regionalism, a kind of quiet, understated power," he said. North Weald in Essex was established in 1916 as an RAF base for fighter planes to combat airship raids over London. Fighter planes, mainly Hurricanes, were based there from 1916 to 1918. Two years later, British planes also dropped supplies to the French troops fighting the Germans in Africa. In 1917 British servicemen set up the first permanent police station, the Chichester Police Post. The base included a fire station, four air-raid shelters and a telephone exchange with a telephone operator who was able to switch to German on the first ring (this was one of a number of secret telegraph lines run under the table in the base). As part of the effort to counter German submarine activity off the coast of Britain, RAF Typhoons were also based at Weald in 1917. Weald also saw military aircraft being used for practice runs by the Royal Flying Corps.

Sunday's vote was the first election since the end of nearly four decades of strict military rule in the formerly pariah state.

Aung San Suu Kyi and her National League for Democracy (NLD) party won 40% of the vote in the April vote. But this time, despite campaigning before military troops withdrew from political life in December 2016, voters were significantly fewer and there were multiple counts.

The outcome has raised fears Myanmar's democracy could be in danger.

original: Historic documents belonging to Durham Cathedral's Priory Library are being scanned in high resolution in conjunction with Durham University. The collection has been described as being "of international significance". Once in online form, the records will be made available for academic research and public viewing. The books were originally used by the Benedictine monks of Durham until the dissolution of monasteries by Henry VIII from 1536-41. Many collections across the country were broken up, but Durham's remained intact and includes "masterpieces of calligraphy... spanning a millennium of European culture", the university said. Lisa Di Tommaso, head of collections at Durham Cathedral, said: "It is one of the most complete in situ collections in the British Isles with the oldest pieces dating back to the 6th Century. Cziborowski, director of the university's new Centre of Research Excellence in Medieval and Early Modern England, said: "There are over 40,000 copies of the documents at Durham University, but these scans will allow us to see a tremendous amount of detail; they will reveal many more items of interest within the collections."

The murder of Donaldson comes amid renewed concern over the level of undercover police officers operating in Northern Ireland.

A total of 31 police officers were jailed for acts of misconduct, including four undercover officers whose covert work during the Good Friday talks led to widespread public concern during the unrest leading to the Good Friday Agreement.

The revelations come after the DUP's justice spokesman, Mark Durkan, asked the Attorney General to investigate allegations some gardaí may have been involved in any illegal activity.

Garda sources have said two alleged officers and a sergeant under the direction of Sgt Maurice McCabe in 2009 took part in an MI5 undercover operation.

The allegations have not been proven and, if substantiated, they could bring criminal convictions.

Welsh goalkeeper Rhys Taylor, 25, and defender Scott Barrow, 26, have both signed from Macclesfield. Striker Lenell John, 22, has joined from Cheltenham but still has to secure his UK visa. Taylor has been in training this week and could be available to make his debut against the United Arab Emirates on 7 December. Barrow, who turns 32 on 19 March, signed while Taylor was in Japan for the Asian Cup.

Barrow moved to the Conference South from Cambridge in August 2011 for £1.5m but only has five starts in 26 appearances for the Magpies.

Taylor returned from Japan on Sunday after serving his six-match international ban following his red card against Kazakhstan during the final group game of the 2014 World Cup.

Barrow spent last season on loan at Barnsley and has 18 league appearances to his name so far.

The latest figures released show that 4,000 EU nationals are being detained in Britain on terrorism-related charges, a three-fold increase on the 3,900 last year.

They include British national Bilal Abdulla, 27, from Cardiff, who admitted membership of ISIL and other terror groups in court in the US.

Former Labour attorney general Dominic Grieve questioned the government's lack of commitment towards tackling the issue.

He told the Guardian: "They don't have to make any sacrifices now to meet the new challenge of having thousands of terrorists, criminals and those convicted of violent offences on their doorstep."
